bioghist.p: Adin Paul Brooks (1892-1987) was a missionary in India from 1923 to 1958. He held a Master's in chemistry from George Washington University and served in the Chemical Warfare Service, Research Division of the U.S. Army before beginning his missionary service. He retired in 1962. Marian Easter (Skinner) Brooks (1893-1924) was the first wife of Adin Brooks. She was a missionary in India from 1923 to 1924. Eleanor Nix-James Brooks (1904-1981), Brooks's second wife, was born in Calcutta, India, and returned to that country in 1950 as a missionary after marrying Brooks. Eleanor Brooks was a registered nurse and midwife. Hattie Estella Brooks (1894-1979) was the sister of Adin Brooks. She held bachelor's degrees from the from University of Illinois (in education and psychology) and the University of Maryland (in home economics). She served as a teacher of Home Economics at Allahabad Agricultural Institute.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of the Brooks family. Materials include: correspondence; photographs and negatives; manuscripts; reminiscences; reports; and clippings of Adin Paul Brooks, Marian Easter (Skinner) Brooks, Eleanor Mary Nix-James Brooks, and Hattie Estella Brooks, relating to mission work at Agricultural Institute of Allahabad, India. The collection also includes: a diary of Hattie Brooks, 1945 and 1947; a 1918 letter written on a thin sheet of aluminum; several scientific articles by A. P. Brooks; recollections of the George P. Skinner family by A. P. Brooks; medical records of A. P. Brooks; information on the Extension Study Project at Allahabad; typescript interview with A. P. Brooks for Menaul Historical Society of Presbyterian Church; notes, presumably made by Brooks after a meeting with Gandhi; and postcards. Additionally the collection contains a number of photographs and negatives including: photos of activities at the Agricultural Institute; one photograph of Agricultural Institute students talking to Gandhi at Wardha in 1939; photos from a trip to Chinaand to Kashmir; and photographs of the Brooks family in India (group shots, landscapes, architecture, animals).
